The dam will eventually have an installed capacity of 1,020 MW.{{cite web|title=News: Second Unit of Karun 4 Joins Iran’s National Network|url=http://en.iwpco.ir/Lists/News/DispForm.aspx?ID=94|publisher=IPWCO|accessdate=30 January 2011}} The dam was inaugurated on 6 July 2011 by Iranian President [[Mahmood Ahmadinejad]].{{cite web|title=News: Self-sufficiency in Dam construction; Karun4 Dam Inaugurated|url=http://en.iwpco.ir/Lists/News/DispForm.aspx?ID=117|publisher=Iran Water and Power Resources Development Co.|accessdate=3 September 2011}} ==Objectives== It was built to fulfill the followings: *To produce an average annual hydropower energy as much as 2100 GW-h. *To join the cascade dams on the Karun River, hence regulate the flow in order to supply the water required by the industry and agriculture downstream. *To control the destructive floods of the Karun River. ==Cost== The dam construction was costed 8600 billion Rials financed by public resources including national and local budget, domestic banks facilities, bonds, as well as foreign facilities (finance, loan, etc.).Initial estimate of annual income from the electricity production amounted to 1353 billion Rials (642 Rials per kilo watt hour). ===Build Contractor=== 1. Daelim (Korea) + Sato (Japan): Main Civil Works
2. Ilbau (Austria) + Forman (Iran): Preconstruction Works
3. Machine Sazi Arak (Iran): Hydraulic Steel Structures
4. Farab (Iran) + Harbin (China): Mechanical Equipment
5. Farab (Iran) + Elin (Austria): Electrical I&C and HVAC Equipment
6. IEO (Iran): GIS Switchgear
{{clear}} ==See also== {{stack|{{Portal|Iran|Water|Renewable energy}}}} *[[List of power stations in Iran]] == References == {{reflist}} {{KarunRiverDams}} {{Commons category|Karun-4 Dam}} [[Category:Hydroelectric power stations in Iran]] [[Category:Reservoirs in Iran]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Chaharmahal and Bakhtiari Province]] [[Category:Dams in Iran]] [[Category:Dams completed in 2010]] [[Category:Arch dams]] [[Category:Dams on the Karun River]] [[Category:Energy infrastructure completed in 2011]] [[Category:2011 establishments in Iran]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Chaharmahal and Bakhtiari Province]]

page.title: List of hazing deaths in the United States

revision.comment: copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]]; url trimming of identifying info per[[WP:LINKSTOAVOID]] and [[Template:Citation_Style_documentation#url|Citation Style]]
revision.text:
{{Dynamic list}} [[File:Stuart Pierson, hazing casualty (1905).jpg|right|thumb|In 1905, Stuart Pierson was being initiated into [[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] fraternity, at [[Kenyon College]]. The other students sent him to a railroad bridge, which they believed was not in use; however, an unscheduled train arrived, and Pierson was killed.]] This is a '''list of hazing deaths in the United States'''. This is not an exhaustive list. An exact list is not available because there is no central system for tracking hazing deaths, and the role of [[hazing]] in some deaths is subject to disagreement. Inclusion in this list requires that the incident was described by the media as a hazing-related death. Incidents involving criminal or civil proceedings that did not find a definite link with hazing may still be included if they meet this criterion. According to the National Collaborative for Hazing Research and Prevention at the [[University of Maine]], hazing is defined as "any activity expected of someone joining or participating in a group that humiliates, degrades, abuses or endangers them, regardless of a person's willingness to participate".{{cite web|title=Hazing Research and Prevention|url=http://umaine.edu/hazingresearch/|website=[[Umaine.edu]]|accessdate=15 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819084932/http://umaine.edu/hazingresearch/|archivedate=19 August 2014|df=}} Although hazing is often associated with the activities that take place as a prerequisite for joining a group, it can also include activities that take place as an established member, such as the 2011 death of fraternity brother [[List of hazing deaths in the United States#2010s|George Desdunes]]. There has been at least one university hazing death each year from 1969 to 2017.{{cite web | url=http://www.hanknuwer.com/articles/hazing-deaths/ | title=Hazing Deaths | publisher=Hank Nuwer | date=2017 | accessdate=January 22, 2017}} According to [[Franklin College (Indiana)|Franklin College]] journalism professor Hank Nuwer, over 200 university hazing deaths have occurred since 1838, with 40 deaths between 2007 and 2017 alone.{{cite news|author=|title=Hazing deaths on American college campuses remain far too common|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2017/10/daily-chart-8|work=[[The Economist]]|date=13 October 2017}} Alcohol poisoning is the biggest cause of death. == 1800s == {| class="wikitable sortable" !width=12%| Date of death !width=14%| Victim !width=12%| Organization !width=12%| Institution !width=50%| Notes |- |1838 | {{sortname|John Butler|Groves|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |Franklin Seminary ([[Kentucky]]) |According to family historical records, Groves died in a hazing incident. No further details are available. |- |1847 | {{sortname|Jonathan D.|Torrance|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[Amherst College]] |Torrance left school after suffering from a severe illness that he attributed to upperclassmen soaking his sheets. He eventually died from this illness and Amherst president Edward Hitchcock attributed the death to hazing rituals, which were referred to as "freshman visitation". |- |October 17, 1873 | {{sortname|Mortimer N.|Leggett|nolink=1}} |[[Kappa Alpha Society]] |[[Cornell University]] |Leggett was brought out into the woods at night as part of an initiation ceremony. He died after falling into a gorge while blindfolded. Two members who were guiding him also fell, but survived.{{cite book|last1=Bryant|first1=Hallman|title=Understanding A Separate Peace: A Student Casebook to Issues, Sources, and Historical Documents|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5p9yu8fFSP8C&pg=PA188|year=2001|publisher=Greenwood|isbn=0-313-31165-X|page=188}}{{cite news|title=The tragedy at Ithaca|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/28369691|work=[[Chicago Daily Tribune]]|date=October 20, 1873| page= 4}} |- |June 6, 1892 | {{sortname|Wilkins|Rustin|nolink=1}} |[[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] |[[Yale University]] |A pledge was led blindfolded through the street during his fraternity initiation towards Moriarty's Cafe, a popular student hang-out. He was told to run and did so at top speed. He ran into a sharp carriage pole, injuring himself. He was rendered unconscious, but the injury was not thought to be serious at the time. He suffered an intestine rupture and died five days later of peritonitis.{{cite news|title=Students' prank caused death|work= [[The Monroeville Breeze]]| date= June 9, 1892|page=6 | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/40530142}}{{cite news|title=Much Sorrow At Yale| url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/33447124|work=The Inter Ocean|date=June 12, 1892|page=27}}{{cite news| last1= Dwight| first1= Frederick| title= Quarter-Century Record, Class Of 1894 Yale College|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NEs3v-YlUr4C&pg=PA471|publisher=Kessinger Publishing| year= 2009| page= 471}} |- |September 19, 1885 | {{sortname|Edward|Turnbach|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |Unknown public school in [[Hazleton, Pennsylvania]] |He was made to run through a [[Running the gauntlet|gauntlet]] of schoolmates in which they punched him with their fists. He was punched in the kidneys severely and died several days later.{{cite news|title=Killed By Hazing|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/28638109|work=Chicago Daily Tribune| date=September 20, 1885|page=10}} |- |- |February 20, 1894 | {{sortname|Henrietta|Jackson|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |Cornell University |The fatality was not a freshman, but a female cook who died when undergraduates misdirected chlorine gas into the kitchen as part of a hazing prank. The gas was intended to interrupt the Cornell freshman banquet.{{cite news|title=Cornell Outrage| work= The Sun and the Erie Country Independent|date=February 23, 1894|page= 1 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/49862285}} |- |September 29, 1898 | {{sortname|David C.|Jones|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |Decatur High School ([[Decatur, Illinois]]) |Jones was participating in a hazing custom on September 6 in which all the freshmen boys were put over the fence on the first day of school. There was a "lively" fight as well. Jones injured his spine severely and died at the end of the month.{{cite news|title=Hazing was the boy's death|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/1189266|work=Logansport Pharos-Tribune|date=October 1, 1898|page=18}} |- |October 27, 1899 | {{sortname|Edward Fairchild|Berkeley|nolink=1}} |Kappa Alpha Society |Cornell University |Berkeley was attempting to pin a piece of paper to a tree or bridge (accounts vary) when he fell into a canal and drowned. Members insisted that the errand was not a form of hazing and was merely meant to keep him occupied until his formal initiation later that day.{{cite news|title=Dies on the way to initiation|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/20527066|work=The New York Times|date=October 29, 1899|page=1}} |- |November 22, 1899 |Martin Bergen |Class hazing |Lawrenceville Academy ([[Lawrenceville, New Jersey]]) |12-year-old Bergen died following a hazing tradition called "piling" in which the freshmen boys are forced to pile on top of one another, ending in the upperclassmen jumping on the boys' abdomens with their knees. Bergen ended the session without issue aside from some soreness for 2–3 days. He developed [[peritonitis]] from internal injuries and died several days later.{{cite news|title=Killed by hazing| url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/44265297| work= [[Harrisburg Telegraph]]|date=November 23, 1899}}{{cite news|title=Boy of 12 died from prep school hazing| url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/3756221| work= The World |location=New York, New York|date=November 23, 1899}} |} == 1900s == {| class="wikitable sortable" !width= 12%| Date of death !width= 12%| Victim !width= 12%| Organization !width= 14%| Institution
and location !width= 50%| Notes |- |November 3, 1900 | {{sortname|Thomas Finley|Brown|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[Porter-Gaud School|Porter Military Academy]]
[[Charleston, South Carolina]] |12-year-old Brown was forced to drop blindfolded into a [[swimming pool]]. He dropped approximately {{convert|12|ft|abbr=on}} into the pool, which contained almost no water. He died from internal injuries.{{cite news|title=Death Follows a hazing|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/62280730|work=The Osage City Free Press|date=November 8, 1900|page=6}}{{cite web|title=Grave for Thomas Finley Brown|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/43789665|publisher=Find a Grave|accessdate=17 April 2015}} |- |November 16, 1900 | {{sortname|Hugh C.|Moore|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] |Moore died following the annual "Cane rush"—a tradition in which freshmen were given a special cane that the sophomores would attempt to steal during a scrap. After the pistol sounded to begin the rush, Moore grabbed hold of the cane, eventually finding himself at the bottom of the pile. He was asked a number of times if he was alright, which he answered in the affirmative. When the event ended, Moore was unresponsive and could not be resuscitated. It was determined that he died of fractures to the upper vertebrae of the neck.{{cite news|last1=Saylor|first1=Henry|title=Death of Hugh Chadwick Moore|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V20/PDF/V20-N8.pdf|agency=The Tech|date=November 22, 1900}} |- |December 3, 1900 | {{sortname|Oscar|Booz|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[United States Military Academy]]
[[West Point, New York]] |Booz began at West Point in June 1898 in good physical health. Four months later, he resigned due to health problems. He died in December 1900 of tuberculosis. During his long struggle with the illness, he blamed the illness on hazing he received at West Point in 1898, claiming he had hot sauce poured down his throat on three occasions as well as a number of other grueling hazing practices, such as brutal beatings and having hot wax poured on him in the night. His family claimed that scarring from the hot sauce made him more susceptible to the infection, causing his death. Among other things, Booz had claimed that his devotion to Christianity made him a target and that he was tormented for reading his Bible.{{cite news|title=Father of the victim testifies that his wrote it was hard to be a Christian at West Point|url=http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19001218.2.12#|work=San Francisco Call|date=December 18, 1900}}"Oscar Booz Is Dead", ''Chicago Daily Tribune'', December 4, 1900, p2 The practice of hazing at West Point entered the national spotlight following his death. Congressional hearings investigated his death and the pattern of systemic hazing of freshmen and serious efforts were made to reform the system and end hazing at West Point.{{cite web| title=Bullies and Cowards: The West Point Hazing Scandal 1898–1901| publisher= Greenwood Press|url=http://www.citadel.edu/english/bullies&cowards.html|accessdate=31 January 2009}}{{cite book| last1=Ambrose|first1=Stephen|title=Duty, Honor, Country. A History of West Point|date=1966|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|location=Baltimore|isbn=0-8018-6293-0|page=277}}{{cite news|last1=Hill|first1=Michael|title=West Point Orders About-Face on 108-Year Tradition of Hazing Cadets| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-11-18/news/mn-6568_1_west-point|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 18, 1990}} |- |September 15, 1903 | {{sortname|Ralph|McBride|nolink=1}} |Secret society "L. of S.S.B" |[[Bluffton High School (Bluffton, Indiana)|Bluffton High School]], [[Bluffton, Indiana]] |Fifteen-year-old McBride died five months after he was hazed roughly during the initiation into a high school secret society. Three other boys were hazed roughly at the same time, leading another of the boys' fathers to press charges for assault and battery against the boys. The other boys survived, but McBride developed sepsis and died following a high fever and delirium. Attempts were made to save his life via removing necrotic bone of his leg, but it was unsuccessful. Ten students were tried for assault and battery but were acquitted, citing the lack of proof that the death was related to the hazing instead of an unrelated illness.{{cite news|title=Was death due to hazing?|url=https://newspapers.library.in.gov/cgi-bin/indiana?a=d&d=IJ19030916.1.9#|work=The Indianapolis Journal|issue=Vol. 53, Number 259|date=September 16, 1903}}{{cite news|title=Bluffton Schoolboys Not Hazed In Manner To Cause Much Harm|url=https://newspapers.library.in.gov/cgi-bin/indiana?a=d&d=IJ19031227.1.9#|work=The Indianapolis Journal|issue=Volume 53, Number 361|date=December 27, 1903}}{{cite news|title=Students are acquitted|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/24921175|work=The Green Recorder|date=January 6, 1904|page=6}} |- |November 8, 1903 | {{sortname|Martin|Loew|nolink=1}} |Phi Psi Chi (Local dental fraternity) |[[University of Maryland, Baltimore]] |Shortly after being initiated into ΦΨΧ, German-born Loew was found deceased in his dorm room while his South African roommate was found unconscious.{{cite news|title=Died From Hazing|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1946&dat=19031109&id=k0suAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zH4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=5850,2956698|work=Montreal Gazette|date=November 9, 1903}} Upon awakening, Loew's roommate described the hazing. A week prior, Loew was undressed, blindfolded, and taken into a room where he was laid on a block of ice. He was then carried upstairs to a balcony and thrown over the railing, a drop of 24 feet. Underneath the railing were students holding a sheet. When he fell onto the sheet, he was tossed up and down until he was unconscious. After reviving, he was beaten severely. He was given whisky and [[Quinine#Beverages|quinine]] that evening. The following Saturday, he submitted to an unknown form of hazing and his roommate underwent the same hazing ritual that Loew underwent the weekend prior.{{cite journal|last1=R.I. Pearson & Company|title=The Western Dental Journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hsIIAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA3&lpg=PA3&dq=Martin+Loew+hazing|date=1904|volume=18}} |- |1903 | {{sortname|Ralph|Canning|nolink=1}} |Childhood hazing |[[Barton, Vermont]] |Three young boys, aged 11, 10, and 7, read about hazing practices in college and decided to try it themselves. They built a fire in a pasture behind the schoolhouse and led nine-year-old Ralph Canning to the spot. They heated a number of stones until they were red hot. The boys forced Canning to both sit and stand on the hot stones and held him there despite his screams. The boys then either walked or jumped on him (depending on the source). He was finally allowed to leave and he crawled home, where he died two weeks later.{{cite news|title=Many are badly injured, some of victims disfigured, cases of hazing at girls schools| url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/63185601|work=The Topeka Daily Capital|date=January 15, 1906|page=1}}{{cite news|title=Torture of nine-year-old campanion results in death|url=http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19030727.2.15#|work=San Francisco Call|date=July 27, 1903}} |- |September 1904 | {{sortname|Frank|Miller|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[Purdue University]]
[[West Lafayette, Indiana]] |Miller and other freshmen were taken to a bridge over the [[Wabash River]]. When he refused to cheer for the sophomores, he was stripped, painted black from head to toe (black and gold are Purdue's official colors), and thrown into the river. He was forced to swim until he was exhausted in the very cold water. He died of pneumonia four days later.{{cite news|title=Hoodlumism in Colleges|url=http://newspapers.bc.edu/cgi-bin/bostonsh?a=d&d=BOSTONSH19040924-01.1.3&e=-------en-20--1--txt-IN-----#|work=The Sacred Heart Review|issue=Volume 32, Number 13|date=September 24, 1904|page=3}} |- |April 1904 | {{sortname|Freddie|Fillwock|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |Rawson School
[[Findlay, Ohio]] |Ten-year-old Fillwock was fatally injured during a hazing event by older boys at the school. He was being physically hazed by several boys who were several years older than he when he broke away from the crowd. He ran toward his home but fell, striking the back of his head on a stake. Several other boys piled on top of him. When he was picked up, his spine was injured, his skull fractured, and several ribs were broken. He died several days later.{{cite news|title=Big Boys of Findlay School Fatally Hurt Youngster|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/76877155|work=The Wichita Beacon|date=April 8, 1904|page=2}}{{cite news|title=Died From Hazing|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/15341634|work=Butler County Democrat|date=April 7, 1904|page=1}} |- |October 28, 1905 | {{sortname|Stuart L.|Pierson|nolink=1}} |[[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] |[[Kenyon College]]
[[Gambier, Ohio]] |Pierson was killed while being initiated into a fraternity. He was sent to a railroad track as part of a hazing ceremony, and killed by an unscheduled train.[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020615/1905-11-03/ed-1/seq-1/ Was This Student "Hazed" To Death?], ''Albuquerque Evening Citizen'' (republished in ''[[Chronicling America]]''); published November 3, 1905; retrieved September 1, 2014. |- |February 10, 1906 | {{sortname|William|Taylor|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |A school in [[Lima, Ohio]] |Thirteen-year-old Taylor was buried in a snowdrift after rough hazing by classmates. He died a few days later of pneumonia.{{cite news|title=Hazing kills schoolboy|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/20637004|work=The New York Times|date=February 11, 1905|page=1}} |- |January 3, 1906 | {{sortname|Cecil F.|Leat|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |Hilliard High School
[[Columbus, Ohio]] |On November 9, 1905, Leat was thrown into a rail, then to the ground where he was beaten severely. He died the following January from the injuries.{{cite news|title=Says hazing caused death|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/52020092|work= [[Pittston Gazette]]|date= January 30, 1906| location= Newspapers.com |page= 2}} |- |March 1909 | {{sortname|Charles|Stinson|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |White School
[[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]] |Stintson was strung up by the ankles to a tree near the school and left for an extended period of time. He died several hours after being taken down.{{cite news|title=Hazing Caused Death: Student in an Indianapolis School hung by his ankles|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/53485914|work=Arkansas City Daily Traveler| date=March 23, 1909|page=7}} |} == 1910s == {| class="wikitable sortable" !width=10%| Date of death !width=12%| Victim !width=12%| Organization !width=14%| Institution
and location !width=52%| Notes |- |February 9, 1910 |Clarence W. Gore |Class hazing |[[University of Oregon]]
[[Eugene, Oregon]] |Gore fell ill following a hazing session in November, during which he was told to keep up a bonfire for an extended period of time, resulting in several hours of hard labor. He never recovered from this illness and died in February.{{cite news|title=Hazing has still another victim| work= [[Weekly Rogue River Courier]]| date= February 18, 1910| url= https://www.newspapers.com/image/76100653}} |- |September 27, 1908 |Emil S. Gran |Class hazing |[[Worcester Polytechnic Institute]]
[[Worcester, Massachusetts]] |On September 22, 1908, Gran fractured his spine in the Sophomore-Freshmen cane rush and died several days later from his injuries.{{cite web|last1=Nuwer|first1=Hank|title=Hazing Deaths|url=http://www.hanknuwer.com/hazing-deaths/|website=HankNuwer.com|accessdate=14 May 2018}} |- |September 12, 1912 | {{sortname|William|Rand|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]]
[[Chapel Hill, North Carolina]] |Rand, along with other freshmen, was forced to leave his room after midnight by sophomores and carried onto the football field. The freshmen were forced to dance, sing, and do other hazing stunts on top of a barrel standing on end. At some point he either fell or the barrel was kicked out from under him. He fell on top of a broken bottle on the ground, severing his jugular vein. The four sophomores ran away, while his roommate called for help. Rand bled to death seven minutes after the fall, before medical help could reach him.{{cite news|title=Governor orders investigation in death of student| work= [[Asheville Citizen]]| date= September 14, 1912| page= 1| url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/75882759}} |- |July 24, 1913 |Donald A. Kenny and Christopher Gustin |Fraternal order hazing |[[Loyal Order of Moose]]
[[Birmingham, Alabama]] |Kenny and Gustin died by electrocution during an initiation ritual. The men were made to look upon a red hot emblem of the Order, then blindfolded, disrobed and had a chilled rubber version of the emblem applied to their chests, while a [[magneto]] was attached to their legs and an [[electric current]] was applied to them by a wire to their shoulders. The aim was evidently to make them believe that they were being branded. Both men fainted, but, as it was thought that they were feigning, the lodge officers did not stop the initiation until it was evident that the two were dying and the lodge physician was unable to revive them.''Southern Reporter'' vol. 80, p. 86[[Arthur Preuss|Preuss, Arthur]], ''A Dictionary of Secret and other Societies.'' St. Louis: B. Herder Book Co. 1924 p.258 |- |September 19, 1913 |Francis Obenchain |Class hazing |[[Purdue University]]
[[West Lafayette, Indiana]] |Obenchain died from a broken neck following the "Tank Scrap" tradition, a brutal physical altercation between freshmen and sophomores.{{cite news|title=South Whitley Man Sues Purdue|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/38389394|work=The Waterloo Press|date=September 30, 1915}} |- |May 26, 1914 |William Bowlus |Class hazing |[[St. John's College (Annapolis/Santa Fe)|St. John's College]]
[[Annapolis, Maryland]] |Bowlus was a cadet in the junior class at the time of his death. He, along with several other upperclassmen, attempted to enter a freshman's room to haze the occupants. Five freshmen were in the room at the time and one fired a shot, striking him in the abdomen. The men refused to identify which one fired the shot, and a grand jury declined to indict.{{cite news|title=Freshmen charged with shooting hazer|work=The [[Cornell Daily Sun]]|date=May 27, 1914}}{{cite news|title=Hazing students cleared|url=http://ufdc.ufl.edu/UF00079945/00174|work=Morning Sentinel |location=Orlando, Florida |date= October 31, 1914}} |- |November 25, 1915 | {{sortname|Thurber|Sweet|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[Virginia Military Institute]]
[[Lexington, Virginia]] |Sweet was the 17-year-old son of Chicago millionaire C.A. Sweet when he entered VMI. He left the institute in October, claiming he had been severely beaten by the other students by bayonets. Physician Dr. J.M. Scott attended to him, telling him his spinal injuries might result in paralysis. Sweet's health continued to deteriorate until he died at the hospital on November 25.{{cite news|title=Sweet's death was due to hazing, is general opinion |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/73540881|work=[[Greensboro Daily News]]|date=December 12, 1915|page=32}} |- |October 1916 | {{sortname|Paul N.|Blue|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[Morningside College]]
[[Sioux City, Iowa]] |Blue died following a hazing incident in which the freshmen were given a severe blow to the head. His injury was complicated by diabetes. He became ill following the blow and died later at the hospital.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/72278702|title=Hazing brings death to Iowa college boy| work=[[Santa Ana Register]]|date=October 24, 1916|page=3}}{{cite news|title=Victim of morningside college hazers is dead| url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/56890981|work=The Chanute Daily Tribune|date=October 18, 1916|page=7}} |- |September 24, 1919 | {{sortname|Frank|McCullough|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[Colgate University]]
[[Hamilton, New York]] |Members of the sophomore class left freshmen, including McCullough, on an island to swim back to shore. He drowned.{{cite news|title=Kane boy is drowned in lake at University; Frank McCullough victim of Colgate hazer|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/49800212||work=[[The Kane Republican]]| date=September 25, 1919}} |} == 1920s == {| class="wikitable sortable" !width=10%| Date of death !width=10%| Victim !width=12%| Organization !width=16%| Institution
and location !width=52%| Notes |- |September 21, 1921 | {{sortname|Leighton|Mount|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[Northwestern University]]
[[Evanston, Illinois]] |Mount disappeared on the evening of a class hazing event and was discovered deceased two years later in a hole beneath a pier between heavy slabs of concrete. Several feet of knotted rope were found around the skeleton, and physicians who examined the body gave the opinion that [[lime (material)|lime]] was placed over the body before it was hidden, as well as reapplied several times after to prevent the body from being discovered. Police were suspicious of hazing as a cause of death because another student, Arthur Persinger, was found bound, gagged in the same way, hanging off the pier with his head down toward the water as a form of hazing. Persinger survived.{{cite news|title=Probe Death of Student|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/36999282|work=Lincoln Evening Journal|date=May 1, 1923}}{{cite news|title=Men in hazing death face stiff quiz|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/72381017|work=Santa Ana Register|date=May 2, 1923|page=1}} |- |January 6, 1925 | {{sortname|Reginald|Stringfellow|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[University of Utah]]
[[Salt Lake City, Utah]] |Stringfellow died following several instances of "tubbing", which was a hazing ritual that involved submerging the victim's head underwater for an extended period of time.{{cite web|title=Nowadays We'd Call It 'Waterboarding'|url=https://alumni.stanford.edu/get/page/magazine/article/?article_id=45331|website= Stanford Magazine|publisher=Stanford University|accessdate=11 August 2014}}{{cite news|title=Students to cease tubbing: hazing practice abolished following death of freshman|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/27049422|work=The Ogden Standard-Examiner|date=January 10, 1925|page=3}} |- |September 30, 1928 | {{sortname|Nolte|McElroy|nolink=1}} |[[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] |[[University of Texas at Austin]]
[[Austin, Texas]] |Sophomore football player Nolte McElroy was electrocuted during an initiation ritual in which he was forced to wear wet pajamas and crawl through two bedsprings that had been charged with electric current by connecting them to city lighting wires through a [[rheostat]]. 184 initiates had gone through the same ritual in the 15 years prior, without incident, including 5 before him on that evening. It is unknown why he alone was electrocuted.{{cite news|last1=Hollandsworth|first1=Skip|title=The Greek Way|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cisEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA161&dq=Nolte+McElroy+hazing|work=Texas Monthly| date=March 1991|page=161}}{{cite news|title=College Members Be Called Before Grand Jury| url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/51122621| work= [[Corsicana Daily Sun]]|date=October 1, 1928|page=1}} |} == 1930s == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! width=10%|Date of death ! width=12%|Victim ! width=12%|Organization ! width=14%|Institution
and location ! width=52%|Notes |- |September 13, 1931 | {{sortname|Lloyd|Aune|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[University of Wisconsin–Stout|Stout Institute]]
[[Menomonie, Wisconsin]] |Aune, a freshman, was killed when his spinal cord was severed during a hazing incident in which he was wrestling with sophomores.{{cite news| title=Hazing death inquiry underway|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/15022565|work=Manitowoc Herald-Times|date=September 15, 1931}} Clifford Tweed, one of the sophomores involved in the grappling death, described the event as good-natured: "I had a toe-hold on him when he cried out. All of us picked him up immediately." He suffered a broken spine in the struggle and died a few days later.{{cite news|title=Jury finds student killed by hazing| url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/50994524|work=The Escanaba Daily Press|volume= XXIII |number= 155|date=September 18, 1931|page=1}} |- |April 11, 1935 | {{sortname|Richard|Beitzel|nolink=1}} |[[Phi Delta Theta]] |[[Dickinson College]]
[[Carlisle, Pennsylvania]] |Beitzel was walking through a field as part of a fraternity initiation stunt in February 1935. He fell against a tree stump, injuring his leg. He developed [[sepsis]] and died several weeks later.{{cite news|title=Hazing abolished as result of boy's death|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/63197161|work=The Evening News |location=Harrisburg, Pennsylvania|date=April 19, 1935}}{{cite news|title=Richard Beitzel, College Athlete, Fatally Stricken| url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/41506088/|work=Harrisburg Telegraph|location=Harrisburg, Pennsylvania|date= April 12, 1935|p=19}} |- |February 25, 1936 | {{sortname|Taylor|Lewis|nolink=1}} |High school fraternity |Unnamed high school
[[Miami]], [[Florida]] |In November 1934, Taylor was struck on the hip and spine with a heavy plank during a hazing session. He died a little over a year later at the age of 17. He was confined to the hospital for most of the time between his injury and his death.{{cite news|title=Hazing Results in Boy's Death: Taylor Lewis dies in Miami of injuries received in 1934|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/69512974|work=The Index-Journal |location=Greenwood, South Carolina|date=March 7, 1936}} |} == 1940s == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! width=10%| Date of death ! width=12%| Victim ! width=12%| Organization ! width=14%| Institution
and location ! width=52%| Notes |- |March 10, 1940 | {{sortname|Hubert L.|Spake, Jr.|nolink=1}} |[[Theta Nu Epsilon]] |[[University of Missouri]]–Columbia
[[Columbia, Missouri]] |Spake died following a fraternity initiation ceremony in which he imbibed heavily. He was found face down in bed and was ruled to have suffocated on his pillow.{{cite news|title=Death of student following fraternity initiation probed|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/74486226|work=Santa Ana Register|date=March 12, 1940|page=1}} |- |October 6, 1943 | {{sortname|Wayne|Rogers|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |Appleton High School
[[Appleton, Wisconsin]] |15-year-old sophomore Rogers was assaulted on a church lawn during the evening of September 7, 1943 (the first day of school) by a group of seven others, including seniors from his school as well as a junior high school student and students from [[St. Norbert College]].{{cite news| title= Two in Court After Hazing |location=Appleton, Wisconsin | work= The Milwaukee Journal | date= 26 November 1943}} They clipped hair from his body and applied [[oil of wintergreen]] to his skin. His face began swelling, and he went into convulsions from which he did not recover.{{cite news| title=State will probe into hazing death| url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/73989056|work=Long Beach Independent|date=November 10, 1943|page=14}} An investigation into the death was launched, concluding with an official ruling that the death was due to an unrelated case of [[nephritis]]. Rogers' parents were "extremely dissatisfied" with the conclusion, alleging that an autopsy was not performed on their son and the county coroner had not even been notified of the death.{{cite news|title=Claim Son Died as Result of School Hazing|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/56347689|work=Dunkirk Evening Observer|date=November 26, 1943|page=4}} |- |February 19, 1945 | {{sortname|Robert|Perry|nolink=1}} |[[Phi Beta Pi]] |[[Saint Louis University]]
[[St. Louis, Missouri]] |Perry died a day after he was critically injured in a fire that occurred during his fraternity initiation ceremony. His nude body was coated with a flammable substance: a [[Carbon black|lampblack]] and [[collodion]] mixture. Electrical shocks were administered to his skin. An induction coil short-circuited, lighting him on fire.{{cite news|title=Initiation fatal to medical student|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/70140360|work=Republican-Northwestern|date=February 20, 1945|page=4}}{{cite news|title=Accidental Death verdict on pledge's initiation rites|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/19432271|work=Moberly Monitor-Index|date=February 24, 1945|page=1}} |- |February 20, 1945 | {{sortname|Jack P.|Jarosz|nolink=1}} |Military |[[United States Navy|US Navy]] |Lt. Thomas H. Fike was found guilty of "conduct to the prejudice of good order and discipline" before a general court-martial following the death of Jarosz during a "shellback" ceremony, in which the sailor was told to touch the brass prongs of a trident when he gave a wrong answer. He died by electrocution. The intent was to cause a mild shock. Another sailor had undergone the same ceremony prior to Jarosz and suffered no ill effects. The ship's electrician testified that Fike told him to take all precautions in installing the device and that he witnessed Fike testing it out himself, finding the shock to be mild. Fike was acquitted of manslaughter and neglect charges.{{cite news|title=Officer cleared partly in sea hazing death|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/49464382|work=The San Bernardino County Sun|date=April 3, 1946}} |- |January 26, 1946 | {{sortname|LeRoy Robert|Bragg|nolink=1}} and Stanford Fluitt |Occupational hazing |SS ''[[Frederic W. Galbraith|Frederick Galbraith]]'' |Crew members Bragg, 14, and Fluitt, 16, died aboard the ship from an overdose of [[saltpeter]] during a traditional equator crossing initiation. Crew members who had never crossed the equator were referred to as "pollywogs" and were promoted to "shellback" status following the crossing. During the shellback ceremony, the boys were blindfolded then marched out onto the deck, where they had numbers painted on them. They were then marched back into the mess hall to wait their turn for the next phase of the initiation, which involved drinking the saltpeter mixed with water. Bragg had obtained work on the ship illegally using fraudulent paperwork stating he was 17.{{cite news|title=Officers cleared of hazing deaths|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/28092992|work=The Ogden Standard-Examiner|date=February 20, 1946|page=1}}{{cite news|title=Two die after Ceremony for equator crossing|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/22825777|work=The Galveston Daily News|date=February 19, 1946|page=3}} |- |April 5, 1948 | {{sortname|James|Peterson|nolink=1}} |Senior honorary society |[[Montana State University]]
[[Bozeman, Montana]] |As part of the initiation ceremony for the society, Peterson and other pledges were instructed to break into the campus heating plant to sound a whistle. A night watchman fired a pistol to "bluff" the students, killing Peterson.{{cite news|title=Will file charges against Martin in Bozeman killing| url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/14217658|work=The Daily Inter Lake|date=April 7, 1948|page=7}} |} == 1950s == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of death ! Victim ! Organization ! University ! Notes |- |May 3, 1950 | {{sortname|Dean|Niswonger|nolink=1}} |[[Alpha Tau Omega]] |[[Wittenberg College]] |Niswonger and fellow pledge Jerry Wendell were taken out into the country as part of a hazing ritual in which they were to find their way back to campus. They decided to sit down on the road to wait for a ride, fell asleep, and Niswonger was hit by a truck.{{cite news|title=Hazing Death Action Taken|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/4279944|work=The Marysville Tribune|date=May 16, 1950|page=1}} |- |Weekend of October 7–8, 1950 | {{sortname|Gerald|Foletta|nolink=1}} |[[Sigma Pi]] |[[University of California, Berkeley]] |Foletta was pledging Sigma Pi when he was driven out into the country to find his way back to campus. He was hit by a vehicle while walking back to the university.{{cite news|title=Fraternity suspended after hazing death|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/49396991|work=The San Bernardino County Sun|date=October 12, 1950|page=4}} |- |March 1, 1951 | {{sortname|Allen|Kaplan|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[Northwestern State University|Northwestern State College]] |As part of a class hazing prank, Kaplan was told he was being set up on a blind date atop a bluff overlooking the Red River. There was no blind date, but another student jumped out from behind a bush, pretending to be the date's enraged husband holding a shotgun. He fired the gun into the air. The rest of the boys ran back to campus, but Kaplan never returned. it is unclear what happened next, but he was later found in the river below the bluff.{{cite news|title=Hazing prank ends in death of Louisiana college student|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/48115480|work=The Oneonta Star|date=March 10, 1951|page=1}} |- |May 25, 1951 | {{sortname|Fred|Evens, Jr.|nolink=1}} and Thomas Kleppner |[[Lambda Chi Alpha]] |[[University of Miami]] |Pledges Evens and Kleppner were taken 30 miles away from campus and told to find their way back. They fell asleep on the roadway and were struck by a vehicle. Kleppner was killed instantly, while Evens succumbed to his injuries several days later on May 30.{{cite news|title=Freak car accident claims second victim|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/26444672|work=The Edwardsville Intelligencer|date=May 31, 1951|page=1}}{{cite news|title=Boy run over during Fraternity Hazing|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/53458499/|work=The Daily Notes from Canonsburg, Pennsylvania|date=May 28, 1951|page=1}} |- |October 22, 1953 |Calvin Dougherty |Class hazing |[[Milligan College]] |17-year-old Dougherty was injured in a race ordered by upperclassmen when he ran into a tennis cable. His pancreas ruptured and spleen had to be removed. He died several days later.{{cite news|title=College Freshman dies after hazing accident|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/15913466|agency=Pottstown Mercury|date=October 23, 1853}} |- |February 10, 1956 | {{sortname|Thomas|Clark|nolink=1}} |[[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] |[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] |Clark was taken to a remote spot and told to find his way back to campus. He fell through the ice covering a reservoir and drowned.{{cite news|title=Find Body of Victim in Hazing|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jSsvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vasFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5008,3506533&dq=hazing|work=The Owosso Argus-Press|date=February 18, 1956}} |- |October 7, 1957 | {{sortname|Max|Caulk|nolink=1}} |[[Delta Tau Delta]] |[[University of California, Santa Barbara|Santa Barbara College]] |Caulk drowned during a fraternity ritual in which he was thrown from the pier into the ocean.{{cite news|author1=Mount, Bob|author2=Lyttle, Richard|title=Oxnard college student Max Caulk dies in fraternity hazing at Santa Barbara|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/31915533|work=Oxnard Press-Courier|date=October 8, 1957|page=1}} |- |May 19, 1959 | {{sortname|Henry|Sherwood|nolink=1}} |Letterman's club |Yakima High School ([[Yakima, Washington]]) |Sherwood died from drowning during a session in which he and other initiates were wearing burlap sacks and being paddled in the water. His disappearance went unnoticed for several minutes. His body was located, but revival efforts were not successful.{{cite news|title=High School Hazing Death|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/957141|work=Mt. Vernon Register|date=May 20, 1959|page=1}}{{cite news|title=Moxee youth dies from club initiation hi-jinks|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=860&dat=19590520&id=QX5OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZksDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6726,4904676|work=Ellensburg Daily Record|date=May 20, 1959|page=2}} |- |September 17, 1959 | {{sortname|Richard|Swanson|nolink=1}} |[[Kappa Sigma]] |[[University of Southern California]] |Kappa Sigma pledges were told to swallow a quarter-pound piece of raw liver soaked in oil, without chewing. The meat lodged in Swanson's throat, and he began choking. The fraternity brothers did not tell police and ambulance workers about the hazing ritual, and instead attributed Swanson's respiratory distress to a "nervous spasm". He died two hours later.{{cite news|title=Hazing death investigation is demanded|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1338&dat=19590918&id=zP9XAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HfcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5359,4516766|work=Spokane Daily Chronicle|date=September 18, 1959}} The incident inspired the 1977 film ''[[Fraternity Row (film)|Fraternity Row]]'', as well a ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'' episode titled "Pledging Mr. Johnson".{{cite book|last1=Nuwer|first1=Hank|title=The Hazing Reader|date=January 29, 2004|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-34370-4|page=XXVI}} |} == 1960s == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of death ! Victim ! Organization ! University ! Notes |- |September 11, 1963 | {{sortname|Michael|Murphy|nolink=1}} |High school band |[[Charleston High School (West Virginia)|Charleston High School]], [[Charleston, West Virginia]] |Fifteen-year-old Murphy was killed in a band initiation incident in which three fellow band members were striking his stomach in at attempt to give him a "pink belly".{{cite news|title=State Supt. asks schools to set up stricter disciplinary policies|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/48006884|work=The Raleigh Register|issue=Volume 84, No. 71|date=September 16, 1963}} |- |August 1966 | {{sortname|Lamonte R.|Jenkins|nolink=1}} |Football team |[[Roman Catholic High School]] ([[Philadelphia]]) |17-year-old Jenkins drowned following a hazing incident in which he was thrown into the water by teammates.{{cite news|title=Accidental drowning ruled in hazing death|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/62846255|work=Standard Speaker|location=Hazleton, Pennsylvania|date=August 24, 1996|page=2}} |- |October 9, 1967 | {{sortname|John|Clifton|Everett|Jr|nolink=1}} |Baylor Chamber of Commerce |[[Baylor University]] |Clifton died following an initiation ritual in which he was told to drink a concoction of five different kinds of laxatives and garlic and then run in place.{{cite news|title=Death stirs hazing ban|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/25417276|work=The Daily Chronicle (Centralia, Washington)|date=October 12, 1967|page=9}} He regurgitated the concoction and then [[Pulmonary aspiration|aspirated]] it, causing significant damage to his larynx and trachea. He began to have difficulty breathing while running and soon collapsed. He suffered a hemorrhage in his lungs and died of cardiac arrest.{{cite news|title=Grisly concoction kills college youth at club hazing|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/9882355|work=The Salt Lake Tribune|date=October 11, 1967|page=4}} |- |February 8, 1969 | {{sortname|Scott|Graeler|nolink=1}} |Stag Club |[[Muskingum College]] |Graeler, a college [[American football|football]] player, died of heart failure following an initiation ceremony. The details of the ceremony were not disclosed, but his death was ruled to have been caused by overexertion.{{cite news|title=Heart failure caused death|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/42833728|work=Xenia Daily Gazette|date=April 15, 1969|page=2}} The president of the club, John Falcon, was convicted and fined $100 on a charge of excessive hazing.{{cite news|title=Man given fine in hazing death|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/72788357|work=The Circleville Herald|date=May 24, 1969|page=1}} |} == 1970s == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of death ! Victim ! Organization ! University ! Notes |- |March 1970 | {{sortname|Donna|Bedinger|nolink=1}} |[[Alpha Gamma Delta]] |[[Eastern Illinois University]] |Bedinger and another female student were driven to a wooded area three miles away from Eastern Illinois University and left as the other sorority members drove away. The ritual was known as "pledge sneak". Bedinger ran after the vehicle and tried to catch its rear bumper but missed, striking her head on the road. She died a few days later from head trauma. |- |December 22, 1972 | {{sortname|Fred|Bronner|nolink=1}} |Chi Chi Chi |[[Los Angeles Pierce College]] |Three fraternity members dropped Bronner off on a secluded road with the intention that he would hike back to campus, approximately 10 miles. They told him to think about how "obnoxious" he was. He was found eight days later at the bottom of a 500-foot cliff in [[Angeles National Forest]].{{cite news|title=Pierce trio make pleas in fatality|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/23710671|work=The Van Nuys Times|date=March 16, 1973|page=1}} |- |September 13, 1973 | {{sortname|Mitchell|Fishkin|nolink=1}} |[[Delta Phi]] |[[Lehigh University]] |Fishkin's fraternity brothers intended to drive the pledge to the other side of the mountain, then make him walk back to the fraternity. En route, he jumped from the moving vehicle and died.{{cite news|title=Autopsy ordered in death of student|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/67413076|work=Standard-Speaker |location=Hazleton, Pennsylvania|date=September 14, 1973|page=22}} |- |November 12, 1974 | {{sortname|William|Flowers|nolink=1}} |[[Zeta Beta Tau]] |[[Monmouth University|Monmouth College (New Jersey)]] |Flowers, along with other pledges, was digging a deep hole in the sand (said to be a symbolic grave), when the walls collapsed and Flowers was buried, causing his death. His death spurred an anti-hazing statute in New York.{{cite news|last1=Rangel|first1=Jesus|title=15 Indicted in Rutgers Hazing Death|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/05/04/nyregion/15-indicted-in-rutgers-hazing-death.html|work=New York Times|date=May 4, 1888}} Flowers would have been the first black member of ZBT at Monmouth had he survived.{{cite news|title=Hazing death brings call for ending fraternities|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/19569705|work=The Anniston Star|date=November 24, 1974|page=3}} |- |September 12, 1975 | {{sortname|Theodore|Ben|nolink=1}} |Class hazing |[[Cheyney University of Pennsylvania]] |Freshman Theodore Ben was killed following a class hazing ritual. He slammed into a wall while carrying another student up and down a hallway, a hazing ritual known as a "dog line". His skull was fractured and he fell into a coma. He died four days later at the hospital.{{cite news|last1=Associated Press|title=2 Charged in Hazing Death|work=The Oil City Derrick|date=20 September 1975|page=2}}{{cite news|url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/42430207|title = 2 Men charged with murder in Cheney hazing death|last = |first = |date = September 20, 1975|work = |accessdate = |page = 22}} |- |August 23, 1976 | {{sortname|Samuel Mark|Click|nolink=1}} |[[Pi Kappa Alpha]] |[[Texas Tech University]] |Click was killed during a scavenger hunt as part of a hazing event. He was attempting to collect a letter that was under a railroad tie. He was hit by a train and killed. |- |1976 | {{sortname|Dennis|Rodenbeck|nolink=1}} |[[Phi Gamma Delta]] |[[Iowa State University]] |Rodenbeck died from an allergic reaction after drinking massive quantities of liquor and beer. The chapter was investigated, but no charges were placed. |- |November 5, 1976 | {{sortname|Thomas|Fitzgerald|nolink=1}} |[[Pershing Rifles]] |[[St. John's University (New York City)|St. John's University]] |Fitzgerald was a student at another university who had applied for admission into St. John's and the Pershing Rifles. He was kidnapped and intimidated with a bayonet when the blade accidentally pierced his chest, killing him. |- |April 21, 1977 | {{sortname|Robert|Brazile|nolink=1}} |[[Omega Psi Phi]] (not recognized by national fraternity) |[[University of Pennsylvania]] |Brazile died of a heart attack following weeks of intense hazing that included beatings, paddling, being forced to run long distances, and sleep deprivation. |- |February 5, 1978 | {{sortname|Nathaniel|Swinson|nolink=1}} |[[Omega Psi Phi]] (not recognized by national fraternity) |[[North Carolina Central University]] |Swinson died following a hazing ritual in which he was forced to run several miles and complete a grueling exercise routine. Swinson had [[sickle cell anemia]], which was exacerbated by the strenuous workout.{{cite journal|author1=Parks, Gregory S.|author2=Jones, Shane E.|author3=Hughey Matthew E.|title=Belief, Truth, and Positive Organizational Deviance|journal=Howard Law Journal|date=Winter 2013|volume=56|issue=2|url=http://www.law.howard.edu/dictator/media/229/how_56_2.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304031506/http://www.law.howard.edu/dictator/media/229/how_56_2.pdf|archivedate=2016-03-04|df=}} |- ||{{anchor|Stenzel}}February 24, 1978 | {{sortname|Chuck|Stenzel|nolink=1}} |Klan Alpine |[[Alfred University]] |Stenzel (some sources list his surname as Stevens) was awoken and taken with other pledges, stripped, placed in the trunk of a car, and told to drink a pint of Jack Daniels, a six-pack of beer, and a bottle of wine between them. Three of the men were unconscious when they opened the trunk. He was left in his dorm for several hours until they finally brought him and two other unconscious pledges to the hospital. The other two men regained consciousness after 72 hours, but Stenzel died of severe pulmonary edema.{{cite web|title=Hazed and Accused|url=http://www.crimelibrary.com/photogallery/hazed-and-accused.html?curPhoto=21|accessdate=7 August 2014|publisher=Crime Library|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140403173653/http://www.crimelibrary.com/photogallery/hazed-and-accused.html?curPhoto=21|archivedate=3 April 2014|df=}}{{cite news|last1=Schabner|first1=Dean|title=Hazing Claiming Younger Victims|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=96824|agency=ABC News|date=October 17, 2014}} |- |January 11, 1979 | {{sortname|Bruce|Wiseman|nolink=1}} |[[Theta Xi]] |[[Louisiana State University]] |Wiseman and six other pledges were in the middle of an initiation ceremony in which they were guided blindfolded down a highway. Their fraternity brothers, who were guiding them, attempted to get them off of the road when a car approached, but they failed to do so in time and the group was hit. Wiseman was killed and three others suffered broken legs.{{cite news|title=1 Dead, 5 injured in initiation|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/19827521|work=The Daily News |location=Huntingdon, Pennsylvania|date=January 16, 1979|page=2}} |} == 1980s == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of death ! Victim ! Organization ! University ! Notes |- |-- |August 31, 1980 | {{sortname|Steve|Call|nolink=1}} |Delta Kappa Phi |[[University of Massachusetts Lowell|University of Lowell]] |Call was required to perform extensive [[calisthenics]] as part of his pledging. He died of [[hyperthermia]].{{cite news|last1=Haney|first1=Daniel Q|title=Hazing: the dark and sometimes deadly side of fraternity life|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/69513835|work=The Index Journal|location=Greenwood, South Carolina|date=September 11, 1980|page=9}} |- |January 25, 1980 | {{sortname|Lurie "Barry"|Ballou|nolink=1}} |[[Sigma Nu]] |[[University of South Carolina]] |Ballou choked to death on his own vomit after he passed out from drinking massive quantities of alcohol in a drinking ritual as part of his pledging. His [[blood alcohol content]] (BAC) was 0.46 when he died.{{cite news|title=Appeals court upholds hazing death award|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/69940338|work=The index-journal |location=Greenwood, South Carolina|date=December 2, 1986|page=11}} |- |{{anchor|DK-Ithaca}}April 2, 1980 | {{sortname|Joseph|Parella|nolink=1}} |[[Delta Kappa]] (local fraternity) |[[Ithaca College]] |Parella died after undergoing a long-standing initiation tradition of calisthenics. One source described the events as taking place in a steam room. Another lists Delta Kappa fraternity's initiation rites as involving the 14 pledges doing 100 pushups, running up and down a steep hill, doing 100 more pushups, then sprinting up and down the hill again. Parella began having trouble breathing, so the fraternity brothers carried him into the hallway and removed his clothing to cool him off. He continued to decline, prompting them to administer CPR and called an ambulance. Parrella died from heatstroke.{{cite web|url = http://theithacan.org/accent/going-greek-unaffiliated-greek-organizations-gain-popularity-at-the-college/|title = Going Greek: Unaffiliated Greek Organizations gain popularity at the college|date = February 26, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Ithacan|publisher = |last = Billington|first = Evin}} |- |1981 | {{sortname|Rick|Cerra|nolink=1}} |FEX (local fraternity) |[[University of Wisconsin–Superior]] |Cerra collapsed and died after being forced to do calisthenics while wearing heavy clothing on a hot day.{{cite book|last1=Nuwer|first1=Hank|title=Wrongs of Passage: Fraternities, Sororities, Hazing, and Binge Drinking|date=August 22, 2001|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-21498-X|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lHM9ltEQIU0C&pg=PA250&lpg=PA250&dq=Rick+Cerra+hazing+death}} |- |March 29, 1982 | {{sortname|Victor|Siegel|nolink=1}} |Alpha Omega Lambda |[[Towson University|Towson State University]] |Siegel was killed in a car accident. Sleep deprivation stemming from hazing rituals was considered to be a contributing factor. At the time of his death, Siegel was wearing a Playboy bunny costume and driving to get signatures of alumni as part of the pledging requirements. |- |1983 | {{sortname|Vann|Watts|nolink=1}} |[[Omega Psi Phi]] |[[Tennessee State University]] |Watts died of an alcohol overdose with a BAC of 0.52. Another member of his pledge class said that he had been beaten with switches as well and his head had been shaved. Other members denied the allegation. |- |1984 | {{sortname|Bruce Ward|Goodrich|nolink=1}} |[[Texas A&M Corps of Cadets|Corps of Cadets]] |[[Texas A&M University]] |Goodrich died of heatstroke after performing strenuous calisthenics. Another student was found guilty of destroying evidence (a company exercise schedule) and three others pleaded guilty to hazing charges. |- |1984 | {{sortname|James|Lenaghan|nolink=1}} |Zeta Chi |[[American International College]] |Lenaghan died after a ritual involving eating small plates of spaghetti followed with large quantities of wine. Other fraternity members placed him in a bathtub after he lost control of his bowels, unaware that this was a sign of impending death. His BAC was 0.48 at the time of death. |- |1984 | {{sortname|Jeffrey Franklin|Long|nolink=1}} |Tau Gamma Theta (local fraternity){{cite web|url=http://www.taugammatheta.com/home.htm|title=Tau Gamma Theta Alumni Association & Pioneer Week History at Chico State|publisher=}} |[[California State University, Chico]] |On the night of Long's death, pledges were encouraged to consume two gallons of wine before participating in a drag race. Long was struck by a vehicle driven by another pledge. |- |1986 | {{sortname|Mark|Seeberger|nolink=1}} |[[Phi Kappa Psi]] |[[University of Texas at Austin]] |Seeberger died of alcohol poisoning after he and two other Phi Kappa Psi pledges participated in a fraternity hazing ritual where they were handcuffed in van and made to consume 16 to 20 ounces of rum. His BAC was 0.43.{{cite news|title=Suit settled over fraternity pledge's death|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1991-09-06/news/9109061027_1_seeberger-phi-kappa-psi-alcohol-poisoning|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=September 6, 1991}} |- |February 13, 1988 | {{sortname|James|Callahan|nolink=1}} |[[Lambda Chi Alpha]] |[[Rutgers University]] |Pledges of Lambda Chi Alpha, were encouraged to drink large amounts of alcohol in an attempt to make them sick. An autopsy confirmed that Callahan had a BAC of 0.434 when he died. |- |1989 | {{sortname|Joel|Harris|nolink=1}} |[[Alpha Phi Alpha]] |[[Morehouse College]] |Harris died following a hazing ritual in which pledges were required to recite historical events of the fraternity, and physically punished for errors. Harris eventually collapsed during a ritual involving slaps, blows, and punches. The ritual lasted between three and five hours. Harris was found to have an abnormal heart rhythm linked to congenital heart disease. As a result of his death, Alpha Phi Alpha voted to halt pledging within the fraternity, instead allowing members to join directly. |} == 1990s == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of death ! Victim ! Organization ! University !Cause of Death ! Notes |- |October 19, 1990 | {{sortname|Nick|Haben|nolink=1}} |Lacrosse club |[[Western Illinois University]] |[[Alcohol intoxication]] ([[Blood alcohol content|BAC]] 0.34) |Haben died of [[alcohol poisoning]]. He participated in drinking games required for admission into the lacrosse club, and was found dead in his dorm room the next morning. Haben's teammates said they had carried him there just before midnight, and propped him up with pillows with his face toward the floor, so he wouldn't choke if he vomited. His BAC was 0.34 at the time of his death.{{cite news|last1=Jouzaitis|first1=Carol|title=College Still Stunned By Hazing Death|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1990-11-14/news/9004040230_1_hazing-death-nicholas-haben-fraternity|work=Chicago Tribune|date=November 14, 1990}} |- |1991 | {{sortname|Mike|Nisbet|nolink=1}} |St. Pat's Board |[[Missouri University of Science and Technology|University of Missouri, Rolla]] |[[Choking]] while intoxicated with alcohol |Nisbet was found dead after choking to death on his own vomit after a ritual drinking game required of initiates into St. Pat's Board, an organization on campus which raised money for the annual St. Patrick's Day celebration. |- |March 31, 1992 | {{sortname|Gregory R.|Batipps|nolink=1}} |[[Alpha Phi Alpha]] |[[University of Virginia]] |Traffic collision |Batipps died in a car accident after falling asleep behind the wheel. His roommate told police that Batipps had been deprived of sleep during pledging activities, returned home at 3 am, and leaving a few hours later at 7:30.{{cite news|title=Hazing Suspected In U.va Student's Death|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1992-04-04/news/9204040052_1_hazing-pledge-process-university-of-virginia-student|work=Daily Press|date=April 4, 1992}} |- |1992 | {{sortname|J.B.|Joynt|nolink=1}} |[[Phi Sigma Kappa]] |[[Frostburg State University]] | |Joynt died following a pledge sneak in which pledges were rough-housing with members. |- |1993 | {{sortname|Chad|Saucier|nolink=1}} |[[Phi Delta Theta]] |[[Auburn University]] |Alcohol intoxication |Death from alcohol intoxication following an annual bottle exchange between members and pledges. |- |1994 | {{sortname|Leslie|Ware|nolink=1}} |[[Alpha Phi Omega]] (not recognized by national fraternity) |[[Alcorn State University]] |[[Gunshot wound|Shot to death]] |Ware was shot at 1 am while stealing a chair, by the boyfriend of the chair's owner. The surviving pledges originally said they were retrieving the chair for a member who requested it, but subsequently changed their statement, claiming they were pulling a prank on their own. The chapter was banned and officially inactive at the time. |- |1994 | {{sortname|Terry|Linn|nolink=1}} |[[Delta Chi]] |[[Bloomsburg University of Pennsylvania|Bloomsburg University]] |Alcohol intoxication (BAC 0.40) |Linn died of alcohol poisoning following Delta Chi's pledging "hell night". His BAC was 0.40. |- |February 14, 1994 | {{sortname|Michael|Davis|nolink=1}} |[[Kappa Alpha Psi]] |[[Southeast Missouri State University]] |Polytrauma after brutal hazing |Davis died after being brutally beaten as part of a hazing ritual. He was unconscious when he was driven home and put to bed. He had broken ribs, a lacerated kidney, a lacerated liver, and bruises all over his chest, neck, back and arms. He died from bleeding in his brain.{{cite book|last1=Spiller|first1=Harry|title=Murder in the Heartland: Book II|date=September 15, 2003|publisher=Turner|isbn=1-56311-912-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hyJ9YrgALK4C&pg=PA192&lpg=PA192&dq=Michael+Davis+hazing+lacerated+kidney}} |- |February 10, 1997 | {{sortname|Binaya|Oja|nolink=1}} |[[Theta Chi]] |[[Clarkson University]] |Alcohol intoxication |As part of Oja's initiation, pledges gathered in a semicircle around a bucket and were instructed to take turns drinking hard liquor. If any pledges did not drink the liquor fast enough, they were instructed to guzzle a full glass of beer. The point of the game was allegedly for pledges to drink to the point of vomiting. Oja was found dead the following morning. News reports suggested that he was pressured heavily to drink, but other pledges and various sources both within and connected to Theta Chi reported that Oja was drinking more than the others in an attempt to impress members of the fraternity and that some fraternity brothers tried to convince him to stop drinking. |- |September 29, 1997 | {{sortname|Scott|Krueger|nolink=1}} |[[Phi Gamma Delta]] |[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] |Alcohol intoxication |Krueger died of alcohol intoxication as part of a ritual celebration intended to forge a bond between each freshman and an upperclass mentor. The freshmen at the party were required to collectively consume a certain amount of liquor. M.I.T. officials were reluctant to call it hazing.{{cite news|last1=Goldberg|first1=Carey|title=A Drinking Death Rattles Elite M.I.T.; Latest Fraternity Party Case Underscores Nationwide Problem|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/01/us/drinking-death-rattles-elite-mit-latest-fraternity-party-case-underscores.html|work=New York Times|date=October 1, 1997}} |- |November 11, 1998 | {{sortname|Jack|Ivey|nolink=1}} |[[Phi Kappa Sigma]] |[[University of Texas at Austin]] |Alcohol intoxication (BAC 0.46) |Ivey's parents alleged that fraternity members tricked their son into drinking too much, stripped him down to his underwear, and tied him up before driving him around in the back of a truck on the night of his death in 1998. He died of alcohol intoxication, with a BAC of 0.46. Phi Kappa Sigma settled with his parents for $2 million.{{cite news|title=$2 million settled in hazing death incident|url=http://amarillo.com/stories/2000/08/02/tex_155-3936.shtml|work=Amarillo Globe-News|date=August 2, 2000}} |- |December 11, 1999 | {{sortname|Kevin|Lawless|nolink=1}} |Sigma Tau Omega |[[Iona College (New York)|Iona College]] |Alcohol intoxication |Lawless collapsed and died following the consumption of "large quantities of beer, wine and vodka" at a bar and later at the apartment of one of the fraternity brothers. Another freshman passed out but recovered.{{cite news|last1=Leo|first1=Standora|title=7 college men charged in hazing death: DA|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/7-college-men-charged-hazing-death-da-article-1.865826|work=New York Daily News|date=April 14, 2000}} |- |March 15, 1999 | {{sortname|Stephen|Petz|nolink=1}} |Knights of College Leadership (local fraternity) |[[Ferris State University]] |Alcohol intoxication |Petz died of alcohol intoxication after drinking heavily as part of his initiation. On the night prior to his death, he played a game called the "wheel of torture". Petz's mother explained, "They sat in a circle, [and] would spin the wheel. And when it was your turn to spin, you had to drink what the wheel said." Petz consumed 27 shots of liquor, and passed out. He was found in serious condition at 8 am the next morning. His fraternity brothers drove him to the hospital an hour later.{{cite news|title=Student Dies After Drinking 27 Shots At Frat Hazing|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/a-deadly-haze/|agency=CBS News|date=April 2, 2001}} |} == 2000s == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of death ! Victim ! Organization ! University !Cause of Death ! Notes |- |October 6, 2000 | {{sortname|Adrian|Heideman|nolink=1}} |[[Pi Kappa Phi]] |[[California State University, Chico]] |[[Choking]] as a result of [[alcohol intoxication]] ||After consuming beer and blackberry brandy as part of his initiation ritual, Heideman became intoxicated and was moved to a back room while the rest of the chapter watched strippers who had been hired for the event. When his fraternity brothers checked on him at 1am the next morning, they found him unresponsive; he had aspirated his vomit and asphyxiated as a result of severe alcohol intoxication.{{cite news|last1=Indar|first1=Josh|title=Frat drinking death suit settled|url=http://www.newsreview.com/chico/frat-drinking-death-suit-settled/content?oid=11560|work=News Review|date=October 31, 2002}} |- |Jan. 29, 2001 | {{sortname|Joseph T.|Green|nolink=1}} |[[Omega Psi Phi]] |[[Tennessee State University]] |[[Asthma|Asthma attack]] after intense exercise |Green suffered an asthma attack and died while jogging and doing calisthenics as part of his fraternity pledging. He had a temperature of 39.8 °C (103.7 °F) when he died. |- |November 4, 2001 | {{sortname|Chad|Meredith|nolink=1}} |[[Kappa Sigma]] |[[University of Miami]] |[[Drowning]], while intoxicated with alcohol |After a night of drinking, Meredith was told to swim across Lake Osceola but struggled due to his intoxication. He drowned 34 feet from shore. Meredith's parents sued the fraternity and were awarded $12,600,000, the largest verdict ever awarded in a fraternity hazing death. In 2005, Florida passed the Chad Meredith Act, which allows prosecutors to seek felony charges for hazing. |- |October 10, 2002 | {{sortname|Albert|Santos|nolink=1}} |[[Pi Kappa Alpha]] |[[University of Nevada, Reno]] |Drowning |Santos drowned in [[Manzanita Lake]] as part of a fraternity ritual. It is unclear if the death was a result of hazing or a prank, but the fraternity was banned from UNR following the incident.{{cite news|title=UNR Fraternity Banned After Hazing Death|url=http://www.8newsnow.com/story/1000134/unr-fraternity-banned-after-hazing-death|agency=8 News Now|date=December 16, 2002}}{{cite news|title=UNR death still probed as a hazing|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2002/oct/14/unr-death-still-probed-as-a-hazing/|work=Las Vegas Sun News|date=Oct 14, 2002}} |- |February 12, 2002 (date found) | {{sortname|Benjamin|Klein|nolink=1}} |[[Zeta Beta Tau]] |[[Alfred University]] |Apparent [[suicide]] after brutal hazing |Two Alfred University fraternity members, Bradley Calkins and Thomas Lam, pleaded guilty to assault and hazing charges, respectively, following the suicide of Klein. The men admitted to assaulting Klein on February 9 to prevent him from speaking out against the fraternity's hazing practices. "We were all afraid that if he left, he would get our fraternity in trouble because he was drinking and telling others about hazing practices in our fraternity," one of the men said. Calkins admitted he hit Klein in the head with a boot after binding his hands and feet with duct tape in a hotel room during a regional fraternity meeting. Lam admitted to encouraging the practice and not taking any steps to halt it. While he was still tied up, he was placed in the bathtub with the shower turned on and not released until he promised he would not leave the hotel room. Klein was found deceased three days later in a creek behind the fraternity house of an apparent suicide by drug overdose. He was found with cuts and bruises on his body from the assault. A month after Klein's death, Alfred University voted to eliminate the Greek system from their campus.{{cite news|title=AU Press Release|url=http://www.alfred.edu/pressreleases/viewrelease.cfm?ID=1544|agency=Alfred University|date=March 1, 2003}} |- |February 14, 2002 | {{sortname|Daniel|Reardon|nolink=1}} |[[Phi Sigma Kappa]] |[[University of Maryland, College Park]] |Alcohol intoxication |Reardon died of alcohol poisoning following a hazing ritual. He was comatose for one week before life support was removed.{{cite news|last1=Cohan|first1=Drew|title=Md. fraternity sued for hazing death|url=http://www.cavalierdaily.com/article/2002/11/md-fraternity-sued-for-hazing-death/|work=The Cavalier Daily|date=November 22, 2002}} The chapter is still active on UM's campus, but they have overhauled the way they bring members into the fraternity. The recruitment brochure for the 2012 year says it has "no pledging and no hazing. None. Never. Ever. Pledging and hazing has no place in a brotherhood."{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Jenna|title=Fraternity rush sobers up at University of Maryland and elsewhere|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/fraternity-rush-sobers-up-at-university-of-maryland-and-elsewhere/2012/03/01/gIQAQf6z5R_story.html|work=The Washington Post|date=March 11, 2012}} |- |September 9, 2002 | {{sortname|Kristin|High|nolink=1}} and Kenitha Saafir |[[Alpha Kappa Alpha]] |[[California State University, Los Angeles]] |Drowning |According to a lawsuit filed by the family, on the night they died, they spent several hours at the beach doing calisthenics before being ordered to walk backward into the ocean. Kenitha, who couldn't swim, was hit by a wave and knocked over. Kristin attempted to rescue Kenitha. Both girls drowned. A lawsuit filed by the girls' families alleged that the women had been blindfolded, had their arms tied, and were wearing clothes and shoes when they entered the water.{{cite news|last1=Banks|first1=Sandy|title=Five years later, still haunted by drowning|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/sep/15/local/me-banks15|work=Los Angeles Times|date=September 15, 2007}} |- |March 12, 2003 | {{sortname|Walter Dean|Jennings|nolink=1}} |Psi Epsilon Chi |[[State University of New York at Plattsburgh]] |[[Water intoxication]] |Jennings was pledging Psi Epsilon Chi when he was forced to drink numerous pitchers of water through a funnel. His brain swelled and he died as a result of [[water intoxication]]. The fraternity had lost its recognition by the campus five years prior.{{cite news|last1=Foderaro|first1=Lisa|title=Death in Underground Frat's Hazing Ritual Shakes a SUNY Campus|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/15/nyregion/death-in-underground-frat-s-hazing-ritual-shakes-a-suny-campus.html|work=New York Times|date=September 15, 2003}} |- |Oct. 20, 2003 | {{sortname|Kelly|Nester|nolink=1}} |Sigma Kappa Omega |[[Plymouth State University]] |[[Traffic collision]] |Nester was killed in a car accident in which she and 10 other pledges were blindfolded and packed into an SUV, which lost control and flipped. A lawyer for Nester's family said: "The understanding is that this was to be a punishment trip because some of the pledges hadn't done some of things required of them. The intent was, apparently, either to scare them or drop them someplace, forcing them to find their way home." New Hampshire police said that the driver may have been driving erratically, rocking the Jeep back and forth and jamming the brakes. The sorority was an unrecognized local sorority composed of members who had either left or been kicked out of [[Alpha Sigma Alpha]].{{cite news|last1=Tuz|first1=Susan|title=Ridgefield woman faces suit in fatal hazing of student|url=http://www.newstimes.com/news/article/Ridgefield-woman-faces-suit-in-fatal-hazing-of-250346.php|work=The News-Times|date=July 12, 2004}} |- |September 17, 2004 | {{sortname|Gordie|Bailey|nolink=1}} |[[Chi Psi]] |[[University of Colorado at Boulder]] |Alcohol intoxication |Bailey died of [[alcohol intoxication]] following a fraternity initiation ritual that involved heavy drinking.{{cite news|title=Frat brothers scrawled slurs all over CU student's body|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/frat-brothers-scrawled-slurs-all-over-cu-student-s-body|agency=News 7 Denver|date=Oct 8, 2004}} [[The Gordie Foundation]] was set up in his memory, "to provide today's young people with the skills to navigate the dangers of alcohol, binge drinking, peer pressure and hazing". |- |November 18, 2004 |Steven David Judd |Delta Chi |New Mexico State University |Alcohol intoxication |As part of Delta Chi fraternity's 21st birthday hazing ritual Steven consumed at least 15 shots of hard liquor in a 2-hour period at a local bar. Police reports state that Steven had on at least two separate occasions asked the bartenders not to serve him anymore alcohol and was also served a drink in order to cause him to vomit which was unsuccessful. After returning to his fraternity house he fell down several times hitting his head and was put to bed where he was found unconscious the following morning. He ultimately was taken off life support just 24 hours after turning 21. At the time of his death Steven was a junior Crimson Scholar at New Mexico State University majoring in Computer Science. The university refused to accept any responsibility or make significant changes in their campus policies. Repeated attempt to get the New Mexico legislature to pass a "Cinderella Law" which would have postponed the legal age, for drinking purposes, 12 hours was consistently met with opposition from the liquor lobby and failed each and every time in committee. A memorial scholarship, funded by his parents and friends, has been awarded each year for the student that "has made the greatest contribution toward alcohol prevention and the reduction of high risk drinking at NMSU." |- |November 25, 2003 | {{sortname|Shawn|Davis|nolink=1}} |Occupational hazing |Republic Energy Drilling Company |[[Polytrauma]] |A drilling rig employee received 18-year prison sentence in the hazing death of 23-year-old Shawn Davis, a new employee of Republic Energy Drilling Company. Veteran employees were attempting to initiate Davis by hoisting him upwards via a cable used to pick up pipe and place it on the rig floor. Davis resisted, but the employees succeeded in putting the belt on Davis and hooking him to the cat line. Another employee noted that the kelly, the device located on the rig floor that is used to drill into the ground and spins at seventy rotations per minute, was turning and, based on his experience, he knew that any slack in the cat line could get caught on the kelly as it turned. Unbeknownst to other employees, this is what happened shortly before he was hooked to the cat line. They hastily attempted to unhook the cat line as it pulled Davis out of the door of the top doghouse. Davis was dragged, face first, out of the building. Davis hit the bottom half of the doghouse door, taking it off the hinges. He was then dragged to the kelly bushing where he was spun around approximately ten to twenty times as his body hit several different pieces of equipment and surfaces. They immediately shut down the equipment and called 911, but he died of blunt force trauma.{{cite news|title=Louis Earl GOODMAN, Appellant, v. The STATE of Texas, State|url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/tx-court-of-appeals/1461499.html|agency=Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth|date=March 30, 2006}} |- |March 8, 2004 | {{sortname|William|James|nolink=1}} |Southside Masonic Lodge, [[Patchogue, New York]] |[[Freemasonry|Freemasons]] |[[Gunshot wound|Shot to death]] |James was killed during an initiation ceremony into an unsanctioned "Fellowcrafts Club" attached to a local lodge, when another member mistakenly fired a gun loaded with real bullets instead of blanks. Police say that the members—all Masons—sat James in a chair and placed cans on a small platform around his head. The alleged shooter, Albert Eid, was standing approximately 20 feet away holding a gun. A second man was supposed to knock the cans off when the gun was fired to make the inductee think they had been struck by bullets to create fear and anxiety. Eid had two guns—one with blanks and one with real bullets—and apparently pulled the wrong one out of his pocket and fired, hitting James.{{cite news|title=Man killed during initiation at Masonic Lodge|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2004/03/09/man-killed-during-initiation-at-masonic-lodge/|agency=Fox News|date=March 9, 2004}} |- |February 2, 2005 | {{sortname|Matthew|Carrington|dab=student}} |[[Chi Tau]] |[[California State University, Chico]] |Water intoxication |Carrington was forced to drink large amounts of water and do calisthenics in a basement flooded with raw sewage with fans blowing on him. He died from water intoxication. The ritual dated back 20 years at the fraternity. As a result, California passed ''[[Matt's Law]]'', which allows for felony prosecution of some hazing rituals, which had historically been misdemeanors.{{cite news|last1=Vega|first1=Cecilia|title=Horrifying details in hazing death|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Horrifying-details-in-hazing-death-Police-2694388.php|work=San Francisco Gate|date=March 4, 2005}} |- |Aug. 28, 2005 | {{sortname|Kenny|Luong|nolink=1}} |[[Lambda Phi Epsilon]] |[[University of California, Irvine]] |As result of intense exercise |Luong died after being tackled in a ritual football game that pitted the 10-member pledge group against approximately 40 active members and alumni. The game lasted for more than 3 hours and was played without the use of pads. Prior to the football game, the pledges were forced to complete vigorous calisthenics such as close-fisted pushups on gravel; jumping in the air while standing, landing on their chests without using their hands to break their fall; and drinking two gallons of water in one sitting.{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Brandon|title=Pledge Death Witnesses Break Silence|url=http://www.newuniversity.org/2007/03/news/pledge_death_witnesses_break28/|agency=New University|date=March 5, 2007}} |- |December 10, 2005 | {{sortname|Phanta "Jack"|Phoummarath|nolink=1}} |[[Lambda Phi Epsilon]] |[[University of Texas at Austin]] |Alcohol intoxication ([[Blood alcohol content|BAC]] 0.41) |Phoummarath was given at least four bottles of liquor to drink on the evening of his death. His BAC was measured at 0.41.
